answer_latex:
would also work, but requires to compute the inverse of \emph{A} first.
There is better ways of solving \emph{Ax=b} than that, and \emph{x=

hints_html: Which symbol does Matlab use to indicate a left-division? Is is a good idea to invert A?
hints_latex:
Which symbol does Matlab use to indicate a left-division? Is is a good
idea to invert \emph{A}?
hints_raw: Which symbol does Matlab use to indicate a left-division? Is is a good idea to invert ''A''?
question: A 21
sols_html:
One would use the backslash operator â€œ\â€, and store the answer into a vector called x. The full command in your MATLAB console would look like

x = A\b;

Note that

x = inv(A)*b;

would also work, but requires to compute the inverse of A first. There is better ways of solving Ax=b than that, and x= A\b is one of them. It does not use the inverse matrix (which is costly to compute).
sols_latex:
One would use the backslash operator â\textbackslash{}â, and store
the answer into a vector called \textbf{x}. The full command in your
MATLAB console would look like

\texttt{x~=~A\textbackslash{}b;}

Note that

\texttt{x~=~inv(A)*b;}

would also work, but requires to compute the inverse of \emph{A} first.
There is better ways of solving \emph{Ax=b} than that, and \emph{x=
A\textbackslash{}b} is one of them. It does not use the inverse matrix
(which is costly to compute).
statement_html:
Suppose that \(A\) is a 12 x12 invertible matrix and b is a column vector with 12 entries. Both \(A\) and b have been entered into MATLAB.

What command(s) would you use to compute the vector x that solves the linear system

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x} = \textbf{b}\end{aligned}\]

?
statement_latex:
Suppose that $A$ is a 12 x12 invertible matrix and \textbf{b} is a
column vector with 12 entries. Both $A$ and \textbf{b} have been entered
into MATLAB.

What command(s) would you use to compute the vector \textbf{x} that
solves the linear system

\begin{align*}
A\mathbf{x} = \textbf{b}
\end{align*}?
statement_raw:
Suppose that <math> A</math> is a 12 x12 invertible matrix and '''b''' is a column vector with 12 entries.  Both <math>A</math> and '''b''' have been entered into MATLAB. 

What command(s) would you use to compute the vector '''x''' that solves the linear system
:<math> A\mathbf{x} = \textbf{b} </math>?
